translations.Welcome to the Graasp App Starter Kit: Welcome to the Graasp App Starter Kit
translations.Name: Name
translations.ClickPerButton: Number of clicks per possible interaction
translations.TimelineTitle: Timeline of users interactivities in the simulation
translations.VisitorsTooltip: Unique visitors who interacted with the simulation.
translations.MedianTrialsTooltip: A trial corresponds to a continuous session during which the user interacts with the simulation. For example, 2 trials correspond to the user interacting once, then reconnecting a moment later (minutes, hours, days, ...) and interacting again with the simulation.
translations.RatingsTooltip: Users can rate the simulation from 0 to 5 in Player mode.
translations.ShowTrace: Rocket path is active on simulation start
translations.IsThrustActive: Thrust is active on simulation start
translations.TooltipIsLockedOnTarget: Does the camera follow the physical object?
translations.TooltipLeft: Can be rotated to the left
translations.TooltipRight: Can be rotated to the right
translations.TooltipVelocity: If this parameter is checked, the user can drag the head of the velocity vector. If the velocity is zero at the start, the velocity vector can still be moved from the center of the rocket.
translations.TooltipAsteroid: If this parameter is checked, the user can drag an asteroid around the rocket. When released, the asteroid collides with the rocket, transferring its velocity to it.
translations.RatingQuestion: Do you find the simulation useful?
translations.MainInformationTips: Customise your Space Rocket simulation using the settings below and the reference on the right as a guide. When you are done, click the « Preview » tab to see how users in Player mode will experience the simulation.
translations.UnityTips0: Position values for the space rocket and the camera can be modified in relation to the (X, Y, Z) reference system shown in the image above.
translations.UnityTips1: By default, the rocket is located at the origin, while the camera is at the point (0, -10, 1) and pointing along the Y-axis corresponding to a rotation vector (0, 0, 0) degrees.
translations.UnityTips2: In the simulation, the orientation of an object is specified by three numerical values in degrees. The values correspond to the amount by which the object is rotated about a local copy of the global (X, Y, Z) axes. For example, a rotation of (10, 20, 30) deg will rotate the object 20 deg about the Y-axis, 10 deg about the X-axis, and 30 deg about the Z-axis,
